In recent years, however, the Menominee have bounced back, first by having their reservation restored, and then receiving income from extensive gaming operations which have improved health and educational opportunities.

pages.name: Miccosukee
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Florida Everglades
 • Split from the Seminoles in the 1950s forming their own tribe.

About the Tribe

The Miccosukee live in south central Florida in the middle of the vast marsh known as the Florida Everglades.  They own the Miccosukee Indian Reservation and operate a very successful resort and gaming casino.  Traditionally, the Miccosukee lived in permanent dwellings built on dry hillocks in the middle of the marsh.  They hunted and fished the bountiful wildlife of the Everglades.

The Reservation hosts a yearly powwow which attracts Native American dancers from all across the U.S., Canada and Mexico.  One of the events you can see if you visit the Miccosukee Reservation is alligator wrestling, which is very exciting!  Don’t try it at home!

pages.name: Mira
pages.info:
"You are smart to ask for what you need."

 • Parents: Embarr & Freja

The two twins are playing together, each are rearing up playfully kicking their legs in unison - they are exact mirror images of each other in every way, except for the reverse colors - one is mottled brown with white highlights, the other is white with mottled brown highlights.

The twins acquired their father’s ability to walk on water - they are both playing on the same lake as depicted with their parents Embarr and Freja.

pages.name: Mireldis & Tassel Mouse
pages.info:
"Look for help and you will find it all around you."

Mireldis is a very magical horse in North of North. She brews potions with the help of her magical friends, the Tassel Mice, who gather all of the ingredients Mireldis needs. They add them to the cauldron to Mireldis' specifications and under her watchful eye.

Mireldis brews her potions under moonlight. She is a very mysterious figure and keeps to herself. Over the years she has become a figure of legend who has inspired this song:

Tassel Mouse, Tassel Mouse where do you roam?

I search in the night on a quest far from home.

Tassel Mouse, Tassel Mouse who sent you so far?

The lady so white with the glowing gold star.

Tassel Mouse, Tassel Mouse for what do you search?

I search for a twig to throw in from my perch!

pages.name: Missouri Fox Trotter
pages.info:
THE SCREENSHOT FOR THIS PAGE IS NOT CURRENTLY ARCHIVED

According to Wikipedia, the Missouri Fox Trotter is a horse breed originating in Missouri, United States. It comes from settlers in the Ozark Mountains, around the 19th century. The breed is known for its smooth gaits, stamina, and stock horse abilities. It's name comes from a gait it is known for, called the "fox trot."

pages.name: Mistral
pages.info:
"Do what you mean to do."

 • Parents: Bifrost & Colour

Mistral is an unusual white horse that has particular strange looking mane and tail strongly resembling lenticular clouds - the mane and tail don’t look at all like hair, but rather like flimsy, soft edged clouds. Mistral’s lithe body sparkles like her father’s - she actually has the ability to assume any color she chooses but prefers this color scheme. Here Mistral flies high above a planet, with the curvature of this world demonstrating just how high she is actually flying.  The sun of this planet is just peeking over the horizon.

pages.name: Mjolnir
pages.info:
"A generous heart is good at loving and being loved."

In Norse myths, Mjolnir was the magic hammer of Thor, god of thunder and lightning. When Thor threw Mjolnir, it always return to his hand.

pages.name: Moonbeam
pages.info:
"You were born with a creative spirit. Let your ideas flow freely."

 • Parents: Leonardo & Sarah

This is the same oasis seen in Sunbeam’s portrait, except now it’s night. The moon bathes the oasis in an otherworldly glow. The moon is a large crescent, its silver sickle reflected in the pool of water. Moonbeam stands by the pool, her color and markings an exact opposite of her brother. Her coat is white and glows with the reflection of the moon upon it. She has a brown mane, tail, and fetlocks. She is poised next to the pool, star-struck, stretching her neck towards the heavens as if attempting to kiss the lesser orb of night. Winds of change blow mysteriously through the oasis, gently caressing the trees wide palms, shivers run across the tiny pool.

pages.name: Moonphantom
pages.info:
"Push yourself to take the first step. Be brave!"

 • Parents: Bukefalos & Mireldi

Moonphantom is a male foal. He is wise beyond his years. Some say he was born old. Still, he appears to be a bit gangly and awkward. His legs always look a bit unsteady though they are not. During the day Moonphantom is a light yellow horse. At night Moonphantom’s color is dependent on the color of the moon. When the moon is a low harvest moon Moonphantom is deep red and orange. When the moon is full in the sky he is bright white. On a night of no moon Moonphantom is pure black. The white blaze on his head when it’s visible also changes with the moon to reflect its state. During a bright full moon it’s invisible because Moonphantom is entirely white.

pages.name: Moonsprite
pages.info:
"If someone hurts you, tell her how you feel about it."

 • Parents: Bukefalos & Mireldis

Moonsprite is a ghost white shy female foal. She has the ability to become almost invisible and incorporeal.  She uses this when she is nervous or scared. Like her mother, she loves tassel mice and a very young tassel mouse named Scribee is her best friend. Moonsprite and Scribee spend most of their time in the forest looking for herbs for her mother’s brews. Moonsprite never leaves footprints and is impossible to track. She also never tramples vegetation where she walks.

pages.name: Mohawk
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Northeastern New York State and Southern Quebec near the St. Lawrence River.
 • One of the five original nations of the Iroquois Confederacy.
 • A notable Mohawk is Kateri, also known as "the Pure and Tender Lily", who was beatified by Pope John Paul II.
 • Another notable Mohawk is Jay Silverheels, the actor who played the Lone Ranger’s friend Tonto on television from 1949 to 1957 and in the movies.

About the Tribe

The Mohawk were "guardians of the eastern gate" in the Iroquois Confederacy, which was composed of five tribes that united to end violent conflicts between them.  The Mohawk Nation is matrilineal and women are considered head of household.  The Mohawks are famous for their traditional dress, including the hairstyle they wore when going to war: head shaved except for a narrow strip of short hair from the middle of the scalp to the nape of the neck.  When American patriots conducted the raid known as the Boston Tea Party—they dressed as Mohawks.

Today the Mohawk nation owns a reservation at St. Regis, which straddles the U.S./Canadian border.  Mohawks who have left the reservation for the cities have become renowned builders and engineers.

pages.name: Morewyn & Sprayer Whale
pages.info:
"Letting go of anger and blame gives you more power and energy."

Beautiful Morewyn is an angel of the sea.  She has a dolphin’s hindquarters and cherubic white wings.  Her friend, a sprayer whale, breaches majestically under her, as steam from his three blow-holes blasts out.  This is a dramatic scene of friendly ocean play.

Anger, when it turns to blame, is a waste.  Anger is a powerful feeling that creates energy for change.  So, we tend to cling to it even after it becomes stale. Let it go and your thoughts will turn to fun, positive objectives.  How do you let go of anger?  Decide right now that you don’t care whether or not someone else gets punished.

pages.name: Morongo
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Riverside County, California

About the Tribe

The Morongo Band of Mission Indians is an extremely community conscious tribe in the inland empire region of California.  They have been active in California politics and have given large financial gifts to community organizations such as the American Red Cross.  During the recent California wildfires disaster, the Morongo band provided food and water and services to over 1200 displaced victims staying in Red Cross shelters.

pages.name: Murttie
pages.info:
"Imagine love and joy coming into your life."

 • Parents: Flipper & Ondine

Murttie is a pale purple horse with blue spots like her mother. Her mane and tail are deep purple. She also has her mother’s ears and supernatural ability to blow bubbles, though her bubbles are much smaller and greater in volume. Murttie is standing up to her knees in calm water. Flowering lily pads surround her. Cattails frame the picture in the foreground. Many, many small bubbles are coming from her ears - bubbles have captured butterflies and other unique insects. Murttie loves to play in this matter.

pages.name: Muskogee
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Southeastern U.S., primarily in the present-day state of Georgia.
 • Also known as the Creek people
 • Culturally related to the Shawnee, Choctaw, Chickasaws and Seminoles.

About the Tribe

Descendants of the mound builders of the Mississippian culture.  They were forcibly removed from Georgia to Indian Territory (what is now known as Oklahoma and Arkansas) in the early 19th Century.  Creeks developed a traditional dance/ceremony called the Stomp Dance which they still practice today.

Today, The Oklahoma Creek Nation is a sovereign nation that covers ten counties in east central Oklahoma.  Some Creeks remained behind in their traditional homeland and there is a small Creek reservation in Atmore, Alabama.

pages.name: Mustang
pages.info:
THE SCREENSHOT FOR THIS PAGE IS NOT CURRENTLY ARCHIVED

According to Wikipedia, mustang is a term used to describe free-roaming horses in the Western United States. These horses were brought to the Americas by the Spaniards, and came from domesticated horses. However, these horses are actually feral horses. They are known as a symbol of the West, and are protected by the U.S. Bureau of Land Management. They are also considered controversial by some, as they take up the land and resources needed for the livestock and ranching industries. They are also considered to be an invasive species by some.

pages.name: Navajo
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Notable Creeks have included actor Will Sampson, who played Chief Bromden in the film One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest.
 • The Four Corners region of the American southwest.
 • Culturally related to the Tlingit in the north, and the Apache in the southwest.

About the Tribe

The Navajos migrated south with their brethren, the Apaches, sometime in the 14th Century.  Originally they were from the Pacific Northwest, and their language, Athabasca, is still spoken by the Tlingit tribe in Alaska.  They took up residence in vacant lands abandoned by the cliff-dwelling Anasazi civilization.  The Navajo built permanent dwellings called hogans, which also have a religious significance.  They enjoyed longstanding friendly relationships with the Pueblo people.  Traditional Navajos planted crops and raised livestock.  Their families were matrilineal and married men went to live with the wife’s family.

pages.name: Nerise & Sand-Dollar Crawdad
pages.info:
"This moment is unique. Make it count!"

Nerise, a young water pony, loves to play in the surf as waves crash around her. On this sun-drenched day she is surrounded by her friends who come to play, they are sand dollar crawdads, they like to tuck their legs turtle and body surf. Waves catapult the crawdads from the sea, through the air, to the sand where their legs pop out and they scuttle back into the ocean for more fun. All of them enjoy playing on the beach and the variety of experience that life offers them. The horse Nerise loves to play in the waves where the Sand-Dollar Crawdads surf. Sometimes she takes her own turn surfing the waves.It’s hard to tell sand-dollar crawdads apart from a regular sand dollar. Only when they move do you see that they have legs and a head.

pages.name: Nieva & Shedderpup
pages.info:
"You can always get the help you need. Just ask for it."

Nieva is brown with white crystal mane.  She has curled on the floor of her frozen cave home, lying on top of mounds of blue fur, keeping warm from the severe cold of winter outside. Several large shedderpups are sleeping on and around her.  One prominent shedderpup scratches the back of her neck as copious amounts of blue hair sheds. This is how Nieva keeps warm - and how the shedderpups stay cool. Nieva loves the shedderpup’s gentle warmth.  The pups, so toasty with their overabundance of constantly shedding blue hair love the cool breeze and snowy showers from Nieva’s mane.

pages.name: Nimiipuu
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Columbia River Plateau of the Pacific Northwest U.S., primarily Idaho.
 • Also known as the Nez Perce tribe, meaning "pierced nose" in French.
 • The Nez Perce tribe did not pierce their noses—that was the Chinook tribe.  This confusion was caused by a mistake made by interpreters for the Lewis and Clark Expedition in 1805.

About the Tribe

The traditional homeland of the tribe included the areas surrounding the Snake and Salmon Rivers.  They fished and hunted, traveling with the seasons.  In the face of U.S. expansion, the Nez Perce fought to retain their identity.  In 1877 they trekked north toward refuge in Canada, but finally surrendered due to starvation and disease.  Chief Joseph is probably the most notable Nez Perce.  His statement as he surrendered to federal soldiers is quite famous.  "Hear me, my chiefs, I am tired. My heart is sick and sad. From where the sun now stands, I will fight no more forever."

The Nez Perce are renowned horse breeders, and have developed their own stock by crossbreeding the Appaloosa with the central Asian Akhal-Teke.

The tribal lands today consist of a reservation located in northern Idaho.

Actress Elaine Miles, known for her role on Northern Exposure, and who narrates the tribal stories for this site, is Nez Perce.

pages.name: Nisqually
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: South Puget Sound, Pierce County, Washington
 • The Nisqually call themselves the "Squalli-Absch" which translates as "people of the grass country."

About the Tribe

The Nisqually tribe occupies a reservation east of Olympia, Washington, near the mouth of the Nisqually River.  The southern portion of the reservation was seized during the World War I by the federal government to make room for the Fort Lewis Military Reservation.  Their traditional lifestyle revolved around salmon fishing.  Today, the Nisqually operate a number of salmon hatcheries.

pages.name: Norwegian Fjord
pages.info:
THE SCREENSHOT FOR THIS PAGE IS NOT CURRENTLY ARCHIVED

Norwegian Fjord, also known as simply Fjord, is a small but strong breed from Western Norway. They are always dun colored, and have been used for hundreds of years by Norwegian farmers. They are known to be good tempered, and are one of the oldest and purest breeds.

pages.name: Nuala & Tortoise Blondie
pages.info:
"Feel the magic in your heart. Use it to give you energy."

Tortoise blondies are fond of water and spend a great deal of time floating in the shallows cooling themselves from the tropical summer heat. Preferring lakes and ponds, older members of the species become extremely protective of their water homes. Once a tortoise lays claim to a pond another tortoise would not dare enter unless he was looking for a fight. One would think that such a fight would be physical; on the contrary, this particular species of tortoise compete with their good looks - it’s simple, the one with the most elaborate mane wins.
One day a water horse of exceptional beauty moved into a placid lake, at first the elder tortoise was put out.  She had just moved in without asking!  He wasn’t going to put up with such rude behavior and moved to confront the filly.  Upon seeing her he stopped stunned. She had the most magnificent, long, flowing, angel-like hair.
Now, some years later, the two have become best friends and both share the little lake along with a young family of lotus hedgehogs and a couple of bubble turtles.

pages.name: Nyx & Nebulaphin
pages.info:
"Let your life take you to exciting places."

Nyx is a darkly beautiful horse with a shadowy mane known as a windrunner - she has no wings but can run across the sky with ease. Her hooves produce jets of compressed air that swirls as her rhythmic gait carries her forward and leaves a contrail of multicolored dust in her wake. Her magical friends the nebulaphin swim gracefully through the sky nearby; they too leave a glittering trail.  Nebulaphin are commonly known as "sky dolphins."

Nebulaphin thrust and propel themselves along the multi-hued gasses of the swirling aurora, producing a cacophony of rainbow colors that shimmer, sparkle and glow. Many believe it is the nebulaphin which make the Northern Lights move and undulate, that it is their comet tails of sparkles that makes the Aurora so colorful. Flying horses run and play within the Auroborus, often intertwined with pods of nebulaphin.  Together they make the Auroborus a sight to behold.

pages.name: Obrylin & Grasspool Otter
pages.info:
"A cheerful mind keeps you feeling healthy and strong."

Grasspool otters are six-limbed amphibians who reside in a great underground aquifer beneath the Grassy. They make their home in air pockets within the root systems that hold up the Grassy and live in family units of about 6-7. They are a curious species often looking about to see what’s-going-on, their heads can be seen sticking up out of the many pools that dot the landscape. They communicate in a whistling chirp that sounds more like a bird call. These otters have striking colors spanning the spectrum of blues and purples - their eyes are deep doey brown.

Obrylin is a breed of water horse called a pool diver.  They spend the majority of their time lounging around pool rims of the Grassy. When threatened they will simply slip into the water and disappear. When night falls they retreat to underwater caves. These horses are very timid and though they can be seen from a distance few have seen one close up. Pool divers are sky blue in color and glow softly in the dark. Instead of hooves, the horses’ legs end in delicate fins and they have gills along their long necks. Their eyes are very large and black. Pool Divers are drawn to flute music and have been known to surface quite close to a gifted musician. Sometimes a pool diver will leave a large pearl from a giant freshwater oyster as a gift by a pool’s edge to reward a particularly good player.

pages.name: Ondine & Bubble Turtle
pages.info:
"Make every day an adventure!"

Ondine makes her home in hidden pools and glades.  Her friend is the curious bubble turtle.  Ondine’s special magic is that she is able to run across water as though it were dry land.  Her contrail is comprised of bubbles.  She and her bubble turtle friends use their bubbles to fly.  Bubble turtles are highly prized for their ability to fly and they can be tamed and domesticated to power lighter than air conveyances such as balloons and kites.  Bubble turtles are one of the ways that people can go back and forth from Trails End to the Overgaard Skylands.

pages.name: Osage
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Missouri, Kansas
 • Laura Ingalls Wilder wrote of the Osage in Little House on the Prairie. 
 • Wealthiest Native American tribe due to the discovery of oil on their Oklahoma reservation.

About the Tribe

Osage built permanent villages in the woods of Missouri and Arkansas and went on twice yearly buffalo hunting expeditions in the plains.  They raised corn, squash and vegetables.  They also hunted deer and rabbit.  Thus, the Osage incorporated some aspects of the Great Plains culture as well as being a woodlands tribe.  The Osage clashed with the Kiowa and the Comanche.  George A. custer employed Osage scouts in his campaign against the Cheyenne and Arapaho in 1867. 

The Osage were resettled in "Indian Territory" (Oklahoma) in the 1870s.  Their lives changed forever in 1897 with the discovery of oil on the Oklahoma land that had been allotted to them.  An unbelievably fortunate clause in their treaty with the U.S. allowed them to keep their mineral rights.  But this was not all to the good as unscrupulous non-natives sought to acquire this wealth through fraud or theft.  Since the 1920s, the OSage have been embroiled in tribal governmental and constitutional issues.  The headquarters of the Osage is in Pawhuska, Oklahoma.

pages.name: Paiute
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Great Basin area of Northern California, Oregon and Nevada (Northern Paiute). Mojave Desert areas of AZ, CA, NV and UT (Southern Paiute). 
 • Culture was adapted to desert life. 
 • Diet included rabbits, antelope, fish and wildfowl, rice grass and pine nuts. 

About the Tribe

Life for the Paiutes was a continuous search for food.  They were primarily hunter/gatherers.  Northern Paiutes were allied with the Shoshone, but had conflict with the Washoe people.  Rabbits were important source of food for the Paiutes, and they also used rabbit fur to make winter clothing. They customarily lived in small groups because food was so scarce.  Paiutes built wickiups, cone shaped dwellings made of sagebrush or reeds. 

In 1889, a Paiute from Nevada named Wokova experienced a vision and revealed the Ghost Dance religion.  This religion spread quickly across the west, as Native Americans from all tribes embraced its message.  Federal attempts to suppress this religion led to the Massacre at Wounded Knee in 1890.

pages.name: Pauma
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Pauma Valley, San Diego County, California
 • Name refers to a band of the Luiseno Indians of Southern California.

About the Tribe

The Luisenos have dwelled the area around present day San Diego for 10,000 years.  They form a harmonious bond with the land and its wildlife, both animal and vegetable.  Springs from the mountains feed the canyon wildlife which has sustained the Luisenos throughout their tribal history.

pages.name: Pavonne
pages.info:
"A noble spirit grows from a kind and honest heart."

 • Parents: Balto & Juno

Pavonne is a tiny foal whose coloring and markings are exactly the same as a male peacock, including extravagant tail; she has vivid blue feathers flowing down her neck and breast that transition to a dull-green, brown and gray. The tail train is iridescent blue-green with the characteristic peacock ‘eyes’. Pavonne is standing in a grassy fir-lined glade on top of a rock outcropping on the edge of small pool. It’s the height of spring with wildflowers in full bloom. Pavonne’s tail hangs down elegantly off the side of the rock almost touching the water. She’s a princess in all her courtly attire.

pages.name: Pawnee
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Northern Oklahoma. 
 • Call themselves Chahiksichahiks "Men of Men."

About the Tribe

Pawnee lived in permanent dwellings of sticks, reeds and brush covered with earth called lodges.  The Pawnee were monotheists, believing in one creator of all things.  Pawnee warriors were known for endurance, courage, loyalty and respect for authority.  The Pawnee practiced the Ghost Dance after that religion was introduced to them, in an effort to contact the spirits of deceased medicine men in order to recreate rituals that had been lost.

During the Indian Wars the Pawnee were employed as scouts by the U.S.  They had frequently warred against the Sioux, and this history of conflict was exploited.

The animosity between the Sioux and the Pawnee was dramatized in the movie Dancing With Wolves.  Many contemporary Pawnee objected to the film’s characterization of their ancestors as being hostile and cruel.

pages.name: Pelagos & Nacreleon
pages.info:
"Be gentle with yourself and others."

Nacreleons have mother-of-pearl shells.  These are beautiful beyond description.  They live in grottoes where they tend all manner of sea growth, like gardeners tending an underwater garden. 

Pelagos is a sea-horse of great magic.  His mane and tail seem to be made of sparkling sand granules that ebb and flow with the slowly moving currents.  If you look closely in this picture, you may see that Pelagos has what look like conch shells in place of hooves. 

Sometimes Nacreleons hitch rides with Pelagos.  Then they go on adventures far from home. 

Pelagos reinforces the idea that Sara’s magic has seeped into every corner of the world North of North.

pages.name: Petal
pages.info:
"Plan a sweet surprise for someone."

 • Parents: Beran & Rosebriar

Petal is a white filly with red or pink rose blossoms for her mane. Her coat echoes Beran’s body patterns in green. Here Petal walks through a rose garden with rose flowers at the height of bloom - she’s friendly and curious, sniffing a rose at the end of a Rose Dragon’s tail. Another baby Rose Dragon above her is acting mischievously just in the act of pouring nectar from the heart of a large rose onto the head of Petal. The golden liquid is half-way to its target. It’s a half-second before a mess. 

Petal was born in the middle of the same rose garden where her father and mother, Beran and Rosebriar, met. Hundreds of rose dragons gathered eagerly to await her birth. When Petal stood up and walked for the first time they immediately rushed forward and attached red rose blossoms to her mane and tail. Petal and the rose dragons love to play in the garden. They have been friends from the day of her birth.

pages.name: Petri & Dream Mouse
pages.info:
"Talk about your feelings. Be open and honest."

Dream mice are so named because they send sweet dreams to anyone they share a pillow with.  They can send dreams to horses, too, if they snooze on the horse’s back.  Petri is a leopard-spotted appaloosa, and has two dream mouse friends, Som and Nam.  Petri likes to dream about flying.  Which is good, because she’s an air horse. 

Petri loves her dream mouse friends.  She can tell them how she feels and they don’t judge.

pages.name: Phoenix & Cowlick Grouse
pages.info:
"Learning feeds your sense of wonder."

Phoenix has a mane and tail of gold and orange silk, part feather, part flower, part fire.  Phoenix lives with her magical friend the cowlick grouse by a lovely waterfall.  Cowlick grouse is a goofy bird.  She has a magical crest feather that dangles in front of her eyes.  The magic feather waves when cowlick grouse dances with Phoenix.  The waving feather gives joy and happiness to all who watch.  Phoenix reminds us that reading and learning raises us from the ashes of boredom.

pages.name: Pima
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Gila and Salt River Valley in Arizona (site of the present day city of Phoenix)
 • Also known as the Akimel O’Odham ("river people")

About the Tribe

The Pima organized villages with permanent dwellings with houses surrounding a central kitchen area.  They were extremely accomplished farmers, and developed a sophisticated irrigation system which remained in use for hundreds of years.  They were also noted for textiles and basket weaving. 

Today the Pima reside at the Gila River Reservation in Arizona, where they farm, and at the Salt River Indian Community, closer to the city of Phoenix, where they operate several successful businesses, including a shopping mall.

pages.name: Pirouette
pages.info:
"You have unique gifts. Make the most of the chances they give you."

 • Parents: Amor & Venus

Pirouette is a pure white flying horse with white ribbons and pearls.  Tiny white cherub wings.  The scene depicts a surreal dream, "Pirouette’s Dance". Pirouette is dancing on a mirrored, ice-covered surface. As she dances, heart shaped petals fall from her hooves.  Softly, they flitter onto the icy surface and swirl in her wake. Pearls of satin gloss explode, bounding and skittering across the mirror.

pages.name: Ponca
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Northern Nebraska

About the Tribe

Historically, the Ponca lived in earth covered lodges in permanent villages, and went on seasonal buffalo hunting expeditions.  Their traditional enemies were the Sioux.

In 1879, Standing Bear, a Ponca Chief, was arrested for leaving the reservation without permission.  His court case established Native Americans as "persons within the meaning of the law," and possessing the right of equal treatment under the law.  It took many decades before that concept was universally applied, however.

pages.name: Potawatomi
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Great Lakes region of the northern U.S.
 • Culturally related to the Ojibwas, Chippewas, Ottowas, and part of the Anisinabe nation. 

About the Tribe

The Potawatomi people hunted, fished and farmed in the Great Lakes region. They built bark and mat covered dwellings called wigwams.  They raised beans, corn, melons, squashes, and tobacco.  They built birch-bark canoes.  After contact with European settlers and traders, they traded furs for iron pots and pans, European fabrics, metal buttons, and guns and gunpowder. 

Today the Potawatomi live on tribal land holdings throughout the Midwest U.S.

pages.name: Primrose
pages.info:
"The more you learn, the more you grow."

 • Parents: Royce & Pink Lady

Primrose stands in a winterland paradise.  An Ice Sculpture of a unicorn dominates the scene. The sculpture dwarfs Primrose , and is spangled in a myriad of colors emanating from dancing fairies (similar to the balls of fairy light in Pink Lady’s portrait). These fairies have only a hint of wings and body - bright shining light obscures their facial features. These fairyland creatures shed light upon the Unicorn Statue. Primrose stands with wobbly legs looking at the statue in a cute clumsy imitation of the sculpture.

pages.name: Prisma
pages.info:
"You have the power to control the way you react."

 • Parents: Bifrost & Colour

Prisma is an equine water elemental - this unique breed of horse is one of a kind. Her entire body is made of mist. Her mane, tail, and wings are made of rainbow mist as if internally lit by a multicolored light source. Her body has an aqua white pigment with vibrantly sparkling mist particles. Here, Prisma flies through a summer squall; a rainbow halo frames her body perfectly.

pages.name: Pythia
pages.info:
"Strength is beautiful."

 • Parents: Pegasus & Roxy

Pythia is a brown and black filly with braided mane and tail. The braids are long and snakelike.  Her wings are pure black.  Pythia is going to be a force to be reckoned with when she gets older.  She’s standing next to the mother of all apple trees - clusters of ripe candy apples hang from overloaded branches. One of the apples has floated down to a very tempting level, bursting with flavor. Pythia ignores it as her gaze lifts skyward.  Here is a hint of great power in its infancy.

pages.name: Ran
pages.info:
"Enjoy a life of beauty and ease."

In Norse myths, Ran was the goddess of the ocean. Norse sailors used to call the sea "Ran’s road" and offer her gifts in return for protection on their voyages.

pages.name: Rauni
pages.info:
"Be honest and do things with love."

In Finnish myths, Rauni was the goddess of harvest and abundance. She and her husband Ukko, god of thunder, brought rainstorms to make the crops grow.

pages.name: Reif
pages.info:
"Find a goal that keeps you focused."

Reif and a group of foals have gathered around a crab on the sandy bottom of a lagoon. The crab stands, holding a bit of seaweed in one claw. It appears as if the crab is explaining something to the class. The foals are gathered in a half circle. They are very interested in what the crab is doing.

pages.name: Rhiannon
pages.info:
"See and hear the magic all around you."

In Welsh myths, Rhiannon was the goddess of horses. Her white steed walk faster than any other horse could gallop.

pages.name: Rimfaxe
pages.info:
"Give others the gift of your love."

In Norse myths, Rimfaxe was the horse of Nat, goddess of night. Every night he pulled the darkness and the moon across the sky.

pages.name: Rosebriar & Rose Dragon
pages.info:
"The world is full of freedom and love for you to find."

Rosebrair is a white unicorn who lives in a beautiful garden full of flowering sculpted topiaries and slender poplar trees.

Her best friends are the magical rose dragons, who have roses at the tips of their tails  When animals develop body parts that resemble leaves, twigs or other natural features (some moths have "eyes" on their wings) it is called "mimicry."  Rose dragons didn’t develop their rose tails for protection from predators, however; but because they are so pretty!

Rosebriar is a lovely mare with a white coat and beautiful flossy feathering on her fetlocks and ankles.  Though she can jump very high, she is not an air horse and so she does not fly.

pages.name: Royce & Caperberry Hob
pages.info:
"Trust yourself to choose the path that’s right for you."

The homeland of the Caperberry Hobs is an exotic landscape of giant trees and bushes with a colorful pallette of wild flowers. Caperberry Hobs are diminutive supernatural entities.  They don’t have wings but they are versatile flyers, using magic to float.  Caperberry Hobs make their homes among the Caper plants feeding upon caperberries. 

Royce is a large regal unicorn stallion. Royce and his magical friends are bonded forever but they couldn’t be more different.  This odd couple while fast friends grate upon each other. The stallion strides with confidence with the bearing of a prince, his fairy sidekick darts to and fro like a yappy untrained dog. Despite their differences deep down they care for each other deeply.

pages.name: Ruskin
pages.info:
"Follow your heart and you will create your own success."

 • Parents: Chryso & Sasha

This summer scene is set upon a green grassy hill on a vast windswept delta. Ruskin is a little orange foal with tan stripes. He has miniature vestigial wings. This little tiger-striped foal is rearing up on his hind legs, though he is very young and somewhat awkward - the wings flutter frantically in an attempt to stabilize but have little effect. In the background, a friendly duskpaw cub watches Ruskin’s playful leaping.  In the foreground, irises dot the hillside.

pages.name: Sabelle & Eureka Bunny
pages.info:
"You are a treasure. Unlock the beauty inside you."

When Sabelle hops through a green pasture, she tucks her front legs beneath her and her back legs propel her off the ground. Next to her is a eureka bunny making a mighty jump, his single ear and tail streaming behind him. In the foreground, another eureka bunny stands next to a magic box with his head cocked and a look of revelation on his face. His single ear stands straight up on his head like an exclamation point. Another bunny sniffs the box with his ear flopped down on his head and his tail coiled up like a question mark. 

Eureka bunnies are creatures of thought, intuition and action. Intensely curious, they are drawn to problems, puzzles, conundrums, and confused people. A bunny will sniff and look at all sides of a problem until the answer suddenly dawns upon him, causing his single ear to stand straight up on his head like an exclamation point. Once he gets an idea, the eureka bunny will hop about using charades to try to explain the answer.  This is known as "jumping to conclusions."

pages.name: Scotty & Bearn Terrier
pages.info:
"Make every step you take magical!"

Bearn terriers have an incredible sense of smell. It is so keen, in fact, that they can smell things that don’t normally have a scent, such as emotions, colors, and even magic. With this amazing ability, Bearn terriers can track down virtually anything, even if they’ve never smelled it before. As a result, they are often called upon by North of North residents to locate lost friends and family members and recover treasured possessions. All they need is the faintest whiff of a scent and they will find the most direct route to their quarry.  Scotty’s magic is that he can always remember the way home.  He can never be lost!

pages.name: Santee
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Minnesota, Northern Iowa, Eastern Dakotas. 
 • One of the three subdivisions of the Great Sioux Nation. 
 • Also known as the Dakota Sioux

About the Tribe

The Santee people were originally a woodland tribe, who hunted, fished and farmed.  They are the easternmost subdivision of the Sioux.  Today, a Dakota reservation exists in northern Nebraska.  The name Santee derives from the word Isanti, which means "knife."  The name Minnesota also comes from the Santee words for "smoky water."  The states of North and South Dakota are named for this tribe.

pages.name: Seminole
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Florida, and the Florida Everglades
 • Culturally connected to the Creek Nation and the Miccosukee, who split from the Seminoles in the 1950s. 
 • Fiercely independent, the Seminoles opposed contact with European settlers and traders

About the Tribe

The Seminoles came into existence in the late 18th Century as a result of a Native American exodus from Georgia and Alabama.  The name Seminole is derived from a Muscogee Creek word meaning "runaway."  Since they were formed out of displaced peoples, the tribe rejected any agreements or treaties with European-Americans.  Their fierce resistance to relocation earned them a nickname: "Mikasuki" which translates both as "warrior" and "Red-Stick."  The Seminole fought a successful 7 year war against the U.S. to resist their removal from Florida.  They never surrendered, and this is a source of tremendous pride for the tribe.

Notably, the Seminole accepted escaped African slaves from Georgia and South Carolina into their tribe.

pages.name: Seneca
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: New York state.
 • Westernmost tribe in the Iroquoian Confederacy.

About the Tribe
The Seneca raised corn, beans and squash, which were the staples of their diet. They established villages with permanent dwellings. These villages were moved every generation or so, when food became scarce or the land depleted. In addition to farming, the Seneca went on protracted hunting and fishing expeditions. Women were in control of the household and all matters relating to it, because these hunting expeditions might extend for months at a time. However their society was not strictly a matriarchy, as matters of tribal policy were still left to the men.

Today the Seneca have tribal lands in New York near Buffalo, in Oklahoma, and Ontario.

pages.name: Seraphia & Starfall Beetle
pages.info:
"You already know what to do. Go ahead and do it!"

Seraphia is a winged filly who lives in the upper branches of the Emerald Cloud Trees—at night she makes her home in the soft canopy that softly sways in the evening breeze. In the day she relaxes soaring high above the Grassy.

Starfall beetles spend most of their lives in the upper atmosphere where they fly in great glittering swarms. They live almost entirely on moisture taken from the air. When it is time for them to reproduce, they curl up in a hard shelled ball and hurl to the earth making a pleasant whistling noise as they do so.  The impact buries them up to six inches into the ground. When the young beetles emerge from the ground they spend the first year flying between 5 and 200 feet in the air. Often times they will ball up and fall to earth in what is believed to be a practice run. They are curious and friendly and will congregate around any flying creatures. To see starfall beetle fall is a sign of good luck.

In one year the beetle reaches maturity shedding their glittering shell where upon they ascend to the heavens to join the colony in great glittering clouds. The discarded shell if anyone is lucky enough to find one is valued for its beauty

pages.name: Shawnee
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Ohio River Valley west of the Appalachian Mountains. 
 • Name means "south" or "southerner" in Algonquin. 
 • The most notable Shawnee is probably Tecumseh, who fought on the side of the British against the U.S. during the war of 1812. 

About the Tribe

The Shawnee were historically widely traveled, and established friendly relations with a number of other tribes. Their culture was similar to both the Great Lakes tribes and the Cherokee, whom they had a friendly relationship.  They considered the Delaware (Lenape) their "grandfathers." During the summer the Shawnee gathered into large villages of bark-covered long houses, with each village usually having a large council house for meetings and religious ceremonies. In the fall they separated to small hunting camps of extended families. Men were warriors who hunted and fished. Care of their corn fields was the responsibility of the women. Many important Shawnee ceremonies were tied to the agricultural cycle: the spring bread dance at planting time; the green corn dance when crops ripened; and the autumn bread dance to celebrate the harvest.

Chief Tecumseh is revered in their history as a war leader and prophet. He said:

"So live your life that the fear of death can never enter your heart. Trouble no one about their religion; respect others in their view, and demand that they respect yours. Love your life, perfect your life, beautify all things in your life. Seek to make your life long and its purpose in the service of your people. Prepare a noble death song for the day when you go over the great divide. Always give a word or a sign of salute when meeting or passing a friend, even a stranger, when in a lonely place. Show respect to all people and grovel to none. When you arise in the morning give thanks for the food and for the joy of living. If you see no reason for giving thanks, the fault lies only in yourself. Abuse no one and no thing, for abuse turns the wise ones to fools and robs the spirit of its vision. When it comes your time to die, be not like those whose hearts are filled with the fear of death, so that when their time comes they week and pray for a little more time to live their lives over again in a different way. Sing your death song and die like a hero going home."

pages.name: Serilda & Howling Mossy
pages.info:
"Value your strengths and they will grow."

Serilda is a unique equine who has evolved a living wood barding, tough and distressed and covered in thick moss. Serilda used all of her magic to develop the barding in order to protect her from her enemies.  She lives deep in dark woods where wolves are common. 

Her magical friends are a pack of howling mossies.  Howling mossies look like wolf cubs that have mushrooms and moss growing on their tails and in their fur.

pages.name: Shire Horse
pages.info:
THE SCREENSHOT FOR THIS PAGE IS NOT CURRENTLY ARCHIVED

According to Wikipedia, a shire horse is a breed of draught horse, usually in black, white, or grey. These horses are often used for pulling carts and farm work. The breed was established officially in the 1800s.

pages.name: Shoshone
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: The three subdivisions of the Shoshone lived throughout the western U.S., from the Western Montana and Eastern Idaho to Death Valley, California. 
 • Culturally tied to the comanche, who split from them and moved south toward Texas. 
 • The word "shoshono" means "walking."

About the Tribe

Because of their widespread population, there is no defining characteristic to the Shoshone tribe in terms of livelihood. The eastern Shoshone practiced the buffalo-hunting culture of the plains tribes.  The western Shoshone were subsistence hunter/gatherers like the Paiutes.  The eastern Shoshone used horses.  The western Shoshone walked on foot (there wasn’t enough to feed horses).  The northern Shoshone fished for salmon, like the Nez Perce.

Sacajawea, who guided the Lewis and Clark Expedition was Shoshone.

pages.name: Signy
pages.info:
"Beauty and mystery go hand in hand."

Signy is a popular Scandinavian name we have borrowed as a nickname for Sweden’s Lake Monster of Storsjön, a mythical creature much like Scotland’s Loch Ness Monster. In Sweden they call the monster Storsjöodjuret or Storgläffsn, but we thought those names might be hard to say in English!

pages.name: Skinfaxe
pages.info:
"Let the sun shine through the darkness and light your path."

In Norse myths, Skinfaxe was the horse of Dag, god of day. Every day he pulled the light of the sun across the sky.

pages.name: Sleetmane & Glowball Pooch
pages.info:
"Imagine your wish. Have faith that it will come true."

Sleetmane is a hardt pony. A pony is a small breed of horse, not a foal. Sleetmane’s heavy coat of thick hair protects him from the harsh arctic climate. His magical friends, the glowball pooches, help Sleetmane forage for the grass and vegetation that survives just under the snow’s crust.

The glowballs at the end of the glowball pooches’ tail serve several purposes. When they dig deep into the snow, the glowballs stay on top, which prevents the pooch from getting lost or trapped if there’s a cave-in.

The glowballs can be whipped back and forth for protection. Finally the glowballs can be used to communicate across far distances, as the pooches flash their tails on and off in rapid code.

Sleetmane is a very wise horse. Like other "cold" horses, Sleetmane sometimes helps create Arborium, a special type of metal that is half plant, half golden, silvery filigree.

pages.name: Sleipnir
pages.info:
"You are unique. Let others see what makes you special."

In Norse myths, Sleipnir was a magical eight-legged horse who could run through the air. He belonged to Odin, god of wisdom and king of the Norse gods.

pages.name: Snowflake
pages.info:
"Change whatever you need to change to make things better."

 • Parents: Mjolnir & Iduna

Snowflake is a white foal with long shaggy hair like her brother, only she’s pure white. She excitedly runs over a snowy field in a winter wonderland. Snow sprays out behind her hoofs as she runs. her hair flies back. She has long silky coat, like that of a Maltese terrier. The sky is light gray and snow is falling all around. Snowflake is running home to her parents after having fun in the snow all day.

pages.name: Standardbred
pages.info:
THE SCREENSHOT FOR THIS PAGE IS NOT CURRENTLY ARCHIVED

According to Wikipedia, Standardbred is an American breed best known for its participation in harness racing. The breed is also used in a variety of equestrian activities.

pages.name: Starfrost
pages.info:
"It’s easier to let go of your fear if you know where it came from."

 • Parents: Iceking & Nyx

This little gal has her mother’s looks and coloring but has her father’s wings: though the feathers gradually change colors from the mother’s blue hue to her father’s white at the tips.
She’s exceptionally small—standing between the two pillars of her father’s forelegs. Starfrost is still a bit timid, scared to venture from her father’s protective side. She has just a hint of a growing horn.

pages.name: Summit
pages.info:
"Being with others and being alone can both be beautiful."

 • Parents: Charlie & Mandalay

Summit is a small brown unicorn with a black and white mixed mane and tail—his muzzle is black with a distinctive birthmark on his forehead where a unicorn should be, but is not. He is standing at the entrance to mountain cave peering in expectantly, (as if dared by some other youth to enter the haunted cave). Fallen moss covered rocks lie to either side of the cave.

pages.name: Sunbeam
pages.info:
"Forgiving others helps you let go of hurt feelings."

 • Parents: Leonardo & Sarah

Bright sunlight shines down on this foal, standing in a desert oasis sanctuary. He is a clear reflection of his father with a brown body and white fetlocks. His champaign mane and tail are far more brightly lit, imitating the sun’s rays. Tropical trees and a pool of water complete this desert scene. Sunbeam is just about to dip his head into the pool to cool himself in the heat of the desert; and soak in the refreshing waters.

pages.name: Tewa
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: New Mexico
 • One of the Pueblo peoples

About the Tribe
Like the other pueblo peoples, the Tewa build permanent dwellings out of adobe bricks. Tewa is also the name of a dialect of the Tanoan language, and the people who speak this dialect are also called Tewa. Six pueblo villages speak Tewa, all are located north of Sante Fe, NM.

pages.name: Thor
pages.info:
"Learn to trust in the people who care about you."

In Norse myths, Thor was the god of thunder and owner of the magic hammer Mjolnir. Our word "Thursday" comes from "Thor’s day."

pages.name: Thunder & Blackcomb Lion
pages.info:
"I give you courage. Now you can release your fears."

An impending storm brews in the distance while Thunder stands against the windy updraft with the blackcomb lion at his side. They are equals, partners, side-by-side they prepare for the onslaught of the summer tempest. Before them is a drop of dizzying proportions, a plunging precipice. Ignoring the danger, they lean forward soaking in the elemental energy. In the sky above, violent flashes of lighting imitate the markings found on Thunder’s flank. The blackcomb lion’s fur is jet and gold, the black echoing Thunder’s coloring, the gold sizzling with the energy of lightning. The tail and mane of both horse and lion are similar in their style and coloring.

pages.name: Tigrine & Duskpaw Cub
pages.info:
"No matter what happens, you can choose the peaceful way."

As hot wind sweeps through green waving grasses, the duskpaw cub crouches, its back end raised, ready to pounce. Tigrine faces off, crouching in a similar fashion, ready to bold. They are both sizing each other up. Who is fiercer? Who is more able? Strong and graceful, even though he looks like he’s barely six weeks old, the duskpaw cub, following his natural instinct, plays a game of stare-down with Tigrine. Because duskpaw cubs do not grow like other felines, staying cute as cubs throughout their lives, some say that they never grow up. Likewise, Tigrine has a foal’s body and temperament. They like the same games: that’s why they’re such good friends.

pages.name: Tlingit
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Temperate rainforests of the southeastern Alaskan coast
 • One of the Pueblo peoples

About the Tribe
The culture of the Tlingit is varied and complex. Historically they lived in a land of unparalleled abundance and this provided them the leisure time to create beautiful works of art in painting, carving, textiles and pottery, elaborate totem poles and masks. Tlingit have a saying: "when the tide goes out, the table is set. " This refers to the abundance of shellfish to be had on the beaches of the Pacific Northwest coastline. They also hunted salmon and seal.

The Tlingit culture is organized around clans and houses, each with their own chief. There is no central authority. Society was matrilineal, and men went to live with their wife’s extended families. Children were trained and disciplined by their mother’s brother-rather than their fathers.

Tlingit practiced the potlatch, which is a community gathering with feasting, dancing, music, stories, games and ceremony. The Tlingit built sturdy permanent longhouse dwellings out of the abundant cedar wood to be found in the Pacific Northwest. Today, because of the unique nature of the State of Alaska’s relationship with the Native American peoples living inside its borders, the Tlingit have no reservation, but rather exist as a tribal corporation.

pages.name: Toboggan
pages.info:
"Do funny things that make you giggle."

 • Parents: Iceking & Nyx

This little rascal is the youngest and most adventurous of the foals with many of the carefree attributes often found in young siblings. Here we see him surfing down the side of a mountain in an ice chute; he’s having a blast while on the verge of whipping out spectacularly. He closely resembles his mother blue hide with no wings—he has his father’s horn: large and strong. A contrail of aurora energy trails off the tip of the horn.

pages.name: Tricksy & Cunning Flitkit
pages.info:
"Spend time with true friends who understand you"

Cunning flitkits, which look like plump flying pandas, are loveable misfits. They fully accept who they are and embrace their differences. With the best qualities of cats, foxes, and bats, they are highly adaptable to their surroundings: climbing, running, and flying with equal mastery. In addition, flitkits love to inspire others to think beyond the possible and frequently pop up where they are least expected. They are also fascinated by anything that is creative, different, and goes against the grain. The cunning flitkit teaches us that living creatures have amazing potential and no cage that can hold intelligence and creativity.

 The horse Tricksy is right at home with her magical friends and shares much of their coloring. She also loves to inspire and encourage thinking outside the box and coloring outside the lines.

pages.name: Tsimshian
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Coast of British Columbia just south of Alaska, near Terrance and Prince Rupert
 • Had very friendly tribal relations with the Tlingit and the Haida

About the Tribe
The Tsimshian fished for salmon and halibut. They hunted for seal, sea otters and sea lions. Like the Tlingit, they built large and elaborate longhouses out of wood. Though they share many cultural traits with the Tlingit, they do not share their language.

pages.name: Tugo & Seashell Bug
pages.info:
"Cheerful thoughts give you energy and faith."

Tugo and his friends the seashell bugs live on the verge of a black sand beach, dotted with hundred of holes. As the rainy season fades and the sunshine warms the black sands of bita'galo, thousands of fist-sized creatures, with six legs and what appears to be a green/black/brown tortoise shell on their back, make their way from the dense rain forest to the sun-baked beaches. These are seashells bugs and their favorite food, kelpis root, is now in season. Digging deep holes in the sand, the seashell bugs search for kelpis root. Within just a few hours, the once pristine black sands take on a pock-marked appearance that will soon disappear with the incoming tide. For weeks the seashell bugs will make their home on this stretch of beach, gathering kelpis root and storing bunches of it in one hole or another.

Tugo, an orange-grey water pony, loves to splash and play in the surf to entertain his magical friends, the seashell bugs.

pages.name: Tumbleweed
pages.info:
"Changing your thoughts can change your life."

 • Parents: Skipper & Flora

Tumbleweed is all boy—his coloring is piebald, with bigger black spots than Skipper, but fewer than Flora. The scene depicts Tumbleweed practicing jumping maneuvers. One of his best buddies is a jackrabbit who is demonstrating to Tumbleweed how to properly jump, he’s above and off-center in a stylistic gymnastic pike jump. Tumbleweed is following the jackrabbit’s lead, but not nearly so effortless with more of a bucking motion, his hindquarters and tail up in the air. In the foreground are blue and yellow flowers. Skipper is seen in the distance, watching.

pages.name: Urd
pages.info:
"Believe in life and everything it has to offer you."

In Norse Myths, Urd was one of the three Norns, goddesses who decided the fates of both humans and gods. She and her sisters watered Yggdrasil, a great tree that connected all worlds, from their well.

pages.name: Viking
pages.info:
"Bring all that is good in life to your friendships."

The Vikings were Scandinavian warriors, explorers and traders whose longboats ruled the seas of northern Europe from about 800 to 1066. One Viking band, led by Leif Eriksson, even sailed all the way to North America!

pages.name: Virstan & Malachite Crab
pages.info:
"Value your strengths and they will grow."

Virstan the water horse shares his coloring with his friends the malachite crabs. They live together on the shores of the inland sea surrounded by majestic mountains that rise into the soft blue sky. Large green boulders line the sandy shore, tidal waters lapping at their edges. Malachite crabs are four-feet long and have razor sharp claws. They use their claws to cut away chunks of malachite from boulders on the shore. Malachite crabs consume the rare green mineral to produce their unique shells. Malachite crabs’ eyes shine a brilliant green corresponding with their shells. Meanwhile, Virstan dances in the surf and cools off from the heat of the summer sun. Other Malachite crabs peer humorously from the foaming waves underlit by glowing phosphorous.

The malachite crab is a very curious crab. It gets its name from the malachite stone, which is bright green, and black.

pages.name: Wasco
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Columbia River Basin-Pacific Northwest
 • Spoke the Chinookan language.

About the Tribe
Wasco people lived on the south bank of the Columbia River near the present-day city of The Dalles, Oregon. The Wishram lived on the north bank, and these two people are sometimes considered one and referred to as the Wasco-Wishram. The Wasco-Wishram dwelled between the Plateau and Northwest Coast cultural areas. They spoke the same language.

In spring the Wasco women harvested roots for the Root Feast, a ceremony held in honor and gratitude to the Creator for the reemergence of life after the winter season. They were important middlemen in a vast trade network. From the east they received skins and the customs of the Great Plains tribes, from the west seafood and shells, and they traded with peoples from the north. Salmon was the staple item of trade and their main food source, and were available in abundant quantities in the Columbia River.

The Wasco-Wishram lived in villages each with its own leaders. The winter village was near the river and permanent and their main food source, and were available in abundant quantities in the Columbia River. The Wasco-Wishram lived in villages each with its own leaders. The winter village was near the river and permanent or semi-permanent in nature, with the houses constructed of cedar planks. In the summer they moved from camp to camp fishing, hunting, gathering berries, and digging roots.

pages.name: Waterpearl & NeonTadpole
pages.info:
"You can change what you do and still be yourself."

Waterpearl is related to lien: both are elemental horses born of water. Whereas Lien loves standing, still waters, Waterpearl loves fast running waters. That’s because her best friends, the magical neon tadpoles, love to jump and swim in running water. They like waterfalls best of all. They are neon green, which gives them their name.

pages.name: Whimsy
pages.info:
"Be thankful for the happy times you share with your friends."

 • Parents: Royce & Pink Lady

Whimsy is a fun-loving pink unicorn filly who enjoys frolicking in snow-covered fields with winged otters. Her chaotic little buddies lead her on many adventures, often filled with reckless folly. Today Whimsy a family of winged otters, leads Whimsey along, jumping and sliding along chutes and corridors in, out and through icy terrain—using their wings for greater speed. This delightful scene shows Whimsy playing with adolescent winged otters.

pages.name: Wichita
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: North Texas

About the Tribe
Because of their custom of tattooing the area around their eyes, they became known as the Raccoon People.

The Wichita were skilled builders of wickiups, which were semi-permanent. They left these dwellings in the winter to go north to hunt the buffalo. They were skilled in growing corn (maize).

pages.name: Wodan
pages.info:
"Be the first to say you are sorry."

 • Parents: Mjolnir & Iduna

Woodan is a dun-colored foal covered with long hair like an icelandic pony. His hair is so long and shaggy, only one eye peeps out from his bangs. He has some of the cuteness of a bear cub combined with a sheepdog. This is a boy who loves to play in the snow. Woodan is shown in a snowy meadow full of snow covered boulders and rocks—no trees. A single flower rises above the snow. Woodan is looking down at it with his one eye as though deciding whether to eat it.

pages.name: Yakama
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Washington State, near the Yakima River.
 • Encountered by the Lewis and Clark Expedition.

About the Tribe
Historically, the Yakama Nation comprised 14 different tribes and bands living along the Yakima River, a tributary of the Columbia River. They fished for salmon, steelhead and sturgeon. They also gathered huckleberries, roots, and chokecherries. They were members of a widespread trading network, and traded for horses, dogs, baskets, textiles and other tools and necessaries.

Today the Yakama Nation has a reservation along the Yakima River in Washington State. They operate several successful business enterprises. A notable Yakama tribal member is Elyse Umemoto, Miss Washington 2007-2008 and who won 2nd place in the Miss America 2008 pageant.

pages.name: Zephan
pages.info:
"Look at yourself with kindness and love."

Mirage possums get their name from their unique ability to change color; they are albino naturally, (white furred with pink eyes), but they are born with chameleon like powers that allow them to change color based upon their surroundings. Possums live in giant cabora palm trees that surround pools of pristine water in desolate desert settings.

Cabora palms are unique in the plant kingdom in that they grow fruits of all shapes and sizes. Like snowflakes, no two fruits are the same. Possums thrive among the cabora, never bored-they have endless choices. Possums climb trees to harvest fruit, and then hang upside to devour their meal. When they come near fruit clumps their fur changes color to resemble whatever fruit they are closest to.

Zephan is the friend of many mirage possums. They are kindred spirits: Zephan has the ability to change color, just like they do.

pages.name: Zuni
pages.info:
Details
 • Area: Zuni Pueblo, New Mexico, U.S.

About the Tribe
Historically, Zuni women made pottery according to clan tradition. Clay for the pottery was dug after giving ritual thanks to the Earth Mother. It was first ground, and then sifted and mixed with water. After the clay was shaped into a vessel, it was scraped smooth with a scraper. Then a thin layer of finer clay was applied to the surface for extra smoothness. Then the vessel was polished with a stone. After the piece was painted with home-made organic dyes using a yucca brush, the pottery was fired in kilns. During the firing, silence was observed in order to maintain the original "voice" of the "being" of the clay and its intended purpose. Selling pottery and other traditional arts and crafts is a major source of income for many of the Zuni, and an artisan may be the sole financial support for their immediate family as well as others. They make pottery, clothing, baskets, and Kachina dolls.

The cultural life of the Zuni people revolves around their religion, which is unique from the other Pueblo peoples. They venerate three deities: Earth Mother, Sun Father and Moonlight Giving Mother. They make barefoot pilgrimages and engage in ceremonies honoring birth, coming of age, marriage and death.

Zuni culture has always been extremely placid and tranquil. They have earned a status in the popular culture of the West as a profoundly spiritual and peaceful people.
